items.title: Is Pierre Poilievre’s leadership in trouble?
items.summary_auto: After one MP crosses the floor, and another resigns completely, we look at the turmoil within the Conservative party, and what that means for Pierre Poilievre’s leadership.

items.title: Volunteers work to preserve quarry that was home to Canadian soldiers in the First World War
Daughter of late WWII vet fighting funeral company for compensation after grave found empty
items.summary_auto: A woman from the U.K. was hoping this Remembrance Day would bring closure after a nearly decade-long search for her estranged father’s grave led her to a cemetery outside of Winnipeg. Instead, she's now trying to reach an agreement with a funeral home company after his grave was found empty last year.

items.title: Flight cancellations and delays in U.S. continue to worsen amid government shutdown
items.summary_auto: The pain Americans are facing at airports across the country is expected to get worse this week if Congress is unable to reach a deal to reopen the federal government.

items.title: Trump pardons Rudy Giuliani, others who backed efforts to overturn 2020 election, official says
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump has pardoned his former personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani, his former chief of staff Mark Meadows and others accused of backing the Republican’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

items.title: Fifty years on, Edmund Fitzgerald remembered through song and mystery
items.summary_auto: Great Lakes Shipwreck Museum to honour the 29 crew members lost in Lake Superior sinking on Nov. 10, 1975

items.title: Typhoon Fung-wong blows away from Philippines, leaving 4 dead and 1.4 million displaced
items.summary_auto: Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the northwestern Philippines on Monday after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million others

items.title: We Stand on Guard Once More concert hoping 'to raise as much money as we can'
items.summary_auto: The sold-out concert featuring the best in Newfoundland and Labrador musical talent will be streamed across all local media channels this evening.

items.title: MMA gym owners, coaches ID’d at secretive neo-Nazi event in B.C.
Japanese immigrants fought for Canada during WW I while denied the right to vote
items.summary_auto: For the first time the faces of Japanese Canadian veterans who fought in the First and Second World War are on display on the streets of Vancouver after a century largely unrecognized and their stories untold.

items.title: ‘A literal shoe box’: Why some Toronto renters are avoiding new builds
items.summary_auto: Some Torontonians are opting out of moving into new builds — for reasons ranging from a lack of rent control to poor layouts — at a time tenants are increasingly gaining leverage in the market.

items.title: Brazil’s climate credentials tested by search for oil off Amazon coast
items.summary_auto: In Oiapoque, Brazil, hopes that oil will transform the economy hangs in air, after the government granted state-owned company Petrobras an exploratory license off the remote Amazonian city's coast. At the same time, on the same coast, Brazilian president is hosting the world's annual climate talks.

items.title: Stellantis takes Ontario auto supplier to court over claims of extortion
items.summary_auto: Stellantis and one of its Canadian auto suppliers are battling in court over the price of brake rotors in a dispute that threatens to shutter some auto assembly plants in Michigan.

items.title: Send in the goats! Eco-herd destroys invasive buckthorn one bite at a time
items.summary_auto: Goats in the City arrived at the Flamborough home last week with a trailer of goats ready to bleat around the bush.

items.title: The fight to be heard: 50 years of the James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement
items.summary_auto: This is part one of a three-part series from Radio-Canada about the 50th anniversary of the James Bay and Northern Quebec Agreement.

items.title: Wildlife traffickers moving ‘dirty money’ within web of organized crime, researcher finds
items.summary_auto: The illegal wildlife trade is deeply connected to other forms of organized crime, including arms dealing, drug trafficking and human smuggling, a new study has found.

items.title: Goats 'delight' at Hamilton property as they destroy invasive buckthorn one bite at a time
items.summary_auto: Goats in the City arrived at the Flamborough home last week with a trailer of goats ready to bleat around the bush.

items.title: U.S. Senate takes first step toward ending longest-ever government shutdown
items.summary_auto: The Senate took the first step toward ending the government shutdown Sunday, advancing a funding bill after weeks of gridlock.

items.title: Hall of Famer and former Raptors coach Lenny Wilkens dies at 88
items.summary_auto: Lenny Wilkens, a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame who was enshrined as both a player and a coach, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 88. The family said Wilkens was surrounded by loved ones when he died and did not immediately release a cause of death.

items.title: First flu death of the season in Alberta amid warnings about potentially tough months ahead
items.summary_auto: Alberta has marked its first influenza death of this year's flu season, after last year's season proved the deadliest in more than a decade.

items.title: U.S. warns air traffic could 'slow to a trickle' amid shutdown, mass quitting
items.summary_auto: U.S. airlines cancelled more than 2,700 flights on Sunday as Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned that air traffic across the nation could "slow to a trickle" if the federal government shutdown lingers into the busy Thanksgiving travel holiday season.

items.title: Hosting Grey Cup in Winnipeg hailed as 'a major economic driver' by businesses, politicians
items.summary_auto: Members of Canada’s Armed Forces repelled from a helicopter Sunday afternoon at The Forks with precious cargo — the Grey Cup  — to mark the beginning of Grey Cup week, which will culminate with the CFL championship game on Nov. 16 at Princess Auto Stadium in Winnipeg.

items.title: Thousands fill Bell Centre demanding Quebec suspend law reforming doctors' pay
items.summary_auto: Thousands of doctors, medical students and supporters filled the Bell Centre on Sunday to demand the Quebec government suspend Bill 2. The law links a part of physicians' pay to performance indicators relating to, for example, the number of patients they care for or the number of surgeries performed.

items.title: Alouettes quarterback Davis Alexander to be key figure during Grey Cup week
items.summary_auto: The Grey Cup spotlight will be on Davis Alexander this week in Winnipeg. The Montreal quarterback takes an unblemished 13-0 career record as a CFL starter into the Alouettes' Grey Cup showdown with the Saskatchewan Roughriders on Nov. 16.

items.title: Guardians' Clase, Ortiz charged with taking bribes to rig pitches for bettors
items.summary_auto: Cleveland Guardians pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz have been charged with taking bribes from sports bettors to intentionally throw certain types of pitches, including tossing balls instead of strikes to ensure successful bets.

items.title: Trump administration wants U.S. states to 'undo' full payouts of food aid benefits
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is demanding states "undo" full SNAP food benefits paid out under judges' orders over the past week, now that the U.S. Supreme Court has stayed those rulings — marking the latest swing in a seesawing legal battle over the anti-hunger program used by 42 million Americans.
